content: The "Windstorm Hazard Reduction Plan Act of 1993" was enacted due to the significant losses suffered by the property and casualty insurance industry in 1992 from natural disasters, particularly windstorms like hurricanes and tornadoes. This led to insurers withdrawing from certain regions in the US and territories, affecting policy issuance and premiums. The "Windstorm Hazard Reduction Plan Act of 1993" requires the Director of FEMA to develop a national windstorm insurance program within 90 days. The plan aims to provide affordable insurance coverage for residential structures against wind damage from hurricanes, tornadoes, and other windstorms. The "Windstorm Hazard Reduction Plan Act of 1993" requires the Director of FEMA to develop a national windstorm insurance program within 90 days. The plan aims to provide affordable insurance coverage for residential structures against wind damage from hurricanes, tornadoes, and other windstorms. This includes insurance coverage, building requirements, mitigation measures, incentives for insurers, and coverage for public infrastructure facilities and properties owned by State and local governments. The national windstorm insurance program includes coverage for various properties such as airports, roads, bridges, dams, residential, business, and agricultural properties, as well as properties owned by private nonprofit organizations. It may involve private insurance industry participation, coinsurance, reinsurance, and defining coverage areas and property types. The national windstorm insurance program covers properties like airports, roads, bridges, dams, residential, business, and agricultural properties, as well as those owned by private nonprofit organizations. It establishes premium rates based on risk, adjusts federal assistance based on insurance purchase, and provides incentives for participation. The Director consults with relevant parties in developing the program. The Director consults with federal agencies, state executives, and private insurers regarding windstorm insurance program development. SEC. 4. REPORT. The Director must submit a report to specified committees within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The report includes a written plan, details on disaster assistance provided for property damage from windstorms in fiscal years 1989-1992, and an estimate of the cost of the national windstorm insurance program. The Director must submit a report within 90 days of the Act's enactment, including a plan for the national windstorm insurance program. The report should detail circumstances for coverage of public infrastructure and properties owned by various entities, estimate program costs, and assess the effects of implementation. The Director must provide a report within 90 days of the Act's enactment, outlining the national windstorm insurance program. This report should include estimates on the impact of the program on disaster assistance, the private insurance industry, necessary amendments to related Acts, and any other relevant information.
